description: April 1: Laos has announced that posting or sharing April Fools’ Day jokes about Covid-19 is now punishable by law. According to the Mass Media Department Facebook page, Media Laos, anyone found posting or sharing April Fools’ Day jokes regarding Covid-19 will face up to three years imprisonment and a fine of up to LAK 20 million, approximately USD 2,000.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines
enforcer: National Government

description: Laos Prime Minister Thongloun Sisoulith has ordered the temporary closure of preschools and kindergartens nationwide amid the ongoing global outbreak of the new coronavirus, or covid-19. This order is effective from 17 March.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
school_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Laos Prime Minister Thongloun Sisoulith has ordered the temporary closure of preschools and kindergartens nationwide amid the ongoing global outbreak of the new coronavirus, or covid-19. This order is effective from 17 March.

The Lao government has announced it will close all educational institutions from March 19 until April 21. The previous policy included the closures of only preschools and kindergartens, and the policy had no concrete end date.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
school_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The Laos government announced precautionary measures in schools when all schools reopen on June 2. The policy states that administrative staff, teachers and students must wear face masks at all times at school, and parents must also wear masks while picking up their children. The schools should have soap, hand gel, and hand washbasins for students. Teachers should arrange suitable seating for students with social distancing of at least one metre and everyone must have their body temperature checked before entering school premises.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
school_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Laos Prime Minister Thongloun Sisoulith has ordered the temporary closure of preschools and kindergartens nationwide amid the ongoing global outbreak of the new coronavirus, or covid-19. This order is effective from 17 March.

The Lao government has announced it will close all educational institutions from March 19 until April 21. The previous policy included the closures of only preschools and kindergartens, and the policy had no concrete end date.

The government has announced all students nationwide can go back to schools on June 2, while final-year classes in primary, lower and upper secondary schools began on Monday, May 18.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
school_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Authorities in northern Laos' Huaphan province on Sunday (March 15) called for the temporary closure of 10 traditional border crossings with Vietnam as part of efforts to prevent an outbreak of the Covid-19 (coronavirus).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The Lao government has suspended the issuance of visas for foreign tourists for 30 days. All types of visas on arrival and electronic visas (E-visas) are suspended, the premier said on Wednesday (March 18). Those already holding an entry visa need to get a health certificate from the concerned authorities and declare their movement history. The cabinet temporarily revokes visa exemptions previously granted to some countries. "It means (citizens of countries previously granted visa exemptions) need to approach the Lao embassy or consulate applying for entry visa." Thongloun warned Lao people to avoid travelling to foreign countries, especially by aeroplane or any crowded vehicle. He told the meeting to advise overseas Lao people (who plan to come back to Laos) to suspend their travel plans until the outbreak is under control.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
The Lao government has suspended the issuance of visas for foreign tourists for 30 days. All types of visas on arrival and electronic visas (E-visas) are suspended, the premier said on Wednesday (March 18). Those already holding an entry visa need to get a health certificate from the concerned authorities and declare their movement history. The cabinet temporarily revokes visa exemptions previously granted to some countries. "It means (citizens of countries previously granted visa exemptions) need to approach the Lao embassy or consulate applying for entry visa." Thongloun warned Lao people to avoid travelling to foreign countries, especially by aeroplane or any crowded vehicle. He told the meeting to advise overseas Lao people (who plan to come back to Laos) to suspend their travel plans until the outbreak is under control.

Issuance of entry visas to individuals traveling or transiting countries with increasing COVID-19 infections remains suspended, with some exceptions. In effect from June 2 to 30, 2020.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: The National Taskforce Committee for Covid-19 Prevention and Control has declared that all travelers, whether residents or Lao citizens, must carry a medical certificate before visiting another country, effective July 8.
enforcer: New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Lao authorities have told foreign airlines to check the temperature of their aircrew and passengers before flying to Laos in a move to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus or COVID-19.

The government-led Task Force Committee for COVID-19 Prevention and Control announced on March 4 that all foreign airlines are required to check the temperature of everyone, including pilots, flight attendants and passengers before letting them board a flight, Xinhua News Agency reported.

Anyone with flu or symptoms of the coronavirus must be treated in that country, while people who arrive in Laos and show the symptoms will be taken to a hospital for observation and be tested.
enforcer: National Government

description: Laos: A Ministry of Health notice dated 1 April mandated the immediate suspension of operations for all private hospitals, clinics, and treatment centers. The notice, signed by the Director-General of the Treatment and Rehabilitation Department Dr. Khampua Soudthisombat, is to take effect immediately.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health

description:
Laos: Yesterday, the Ministry of Health made a drastic decision to order all non-state medical centers to cease operations, for fear that private clinics would not have the requisite equipment to test and safeguard their employees against COVID-19. The Ministry of Health has recently amended its policy regarding which types of non-state healthcare facilities will be allowed to open.

Minister of Health Dr. Bounkong Sihavong signed a new notice, dated 2 April, which mandates the temporary closure of all non-specialized private clinics. However, specialized private clinics (heart, pediatric, etc), embassy clinics, and private hospitals shall be permitted to open. However, the abovementioned practices are prohibited from treating COVID-19 cases and must take necessary precautions. They are to call 166 or refer patients to the National Taskforce Committee if they suspect a COVID-19 case.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health

description: In Laos, around May 13, the National Taskforce Committee for Covid-19 Prevention and Control said that they will spend 23.98 billion kip from the state budget and 9.54 billion kip donated by other sectors on: 23 patient monitoring devices to be distributed to central hospitals, 14 ventilators (7 for central hospitals, 7 for regional hospitals), and three equipped ambulances for central hospitals. The state budget will also be used to purchase 20,000 hand sanitizer bottles (3000 for central orgs and 17,000 for regional orgs), 20,000 PPE kits (10,000 for central hospitals, 10,000 for local hospitals), 5 million face masks for central and local medical staff, and 7 equipped ambulances for provincial hospitals.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On May 13, Laotian authorities collected 179 individual samples for testing, which all yielded negative results.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: April 6, 2020: The Lao Ministry of Energy and Mines has ordered the temporary suspension of mineral processing plants and hydropower construction projects under a new notice issued yesterday. The notice, signed by Vice Minister of Energy and Mines Thongphat Inthavong, orders the temporary closure of factories and processing plants following the announcement that an employee of Phu Bia Mining Limited had tested positive for Covid-19. Plant workers are to remain on-site and will be prohibited from traveling to local areas or returning to their villages. They are to receive extra training in the prevention and control of Covid-19, and any employees exhibiting symptoms are to be isolated. The notice requests that strict social distancing protocol be instituted at mining and hydropower sites, with workers to stay two meters apart at all times, while workplaces are to be sprayed and disinfected.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Laos, morning news for April 23, 2020: Cleaning, disinfecting ordered for quarantine facilities: Local authorities will need to clean and disinfect quarantine facilities around the country to stop the spread of COVID-19, according to a Ministry of Health order. The activity will be implemented after people who are self-isolating at quarantine facilities return home. — Vientiane Times (paywall)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description:
Laos initiated a lockdown from March 30 to April 19, where residents are prohibited from leaving their homes except to buy essential goods, go to the hospital, or engage in other essential and authorized tasks.

The lockdown was extended to May 3.

As of May 4, the nationwide lockdown has been lifted, with new measures in place, and some measures remaining.

description: Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order: Pursuant to the Prime Minister's Decree on the Appointment of a Task Force to Prevent, Control and Addressing the Epidemiology of Pneumonia (No. 601), No. 09 / PM, Dated February 03, 2020; - According to the minutes of the Prime Minister-Vice-Presidential Meeting of the 3rd of February, 2020. Five specific missions to prevent, control and respond to outbreaks Of bacterial pneumonia agree: Article 1 Appoints the Secretariat for the Prevention, Control and Response of Epidemics.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government

description:
The Lao Ministry of Post and Telecommunications has announced that all phone numbers across the country must now be properly registered or face permanent disconnection. According to a notice issued by the ministry, the compulsory registration and re-registration of all phone numbers will begin on 1 July this year.

The process will be completed in three phases.

From 1 July to 30 November, all existing phone numbers must be properly registered, and any new numbers and sim cards may not be issued without proper registration.

From 01 December to 31 December, any phone numbers that fail to properly register will be able to receive calls but will not be able to make calls. Data sims will no longer be able to connect to the internet.

From 31 December onward, any phone numbers that are not properly registered will be disconnected and permanently removed from the telephone network.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Laos, 19 Mar 2020: The prime minister called for more campaigns to raise public awareness about the virus and preventative measures.

Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 23, 2020: Advertise to the public and broadly recognize the dangers and risks of infections; how to protect yourself, your family and others; the condition of a suspected infection; and how to get information about the disease, and places of contact for assistance and information that may be available. Upgrade the information center of the Board of Directors to provide guidance and communicate the right, clear, and prompt socialization of epidemiological conditions and coping. Promote publicity for the public to actively participate in the fight against outbreaks. Improve information systems and databases to help plan for coping, informing socially useful information, solving concerns, preventing the distorting of facts, and so on to ensure that the society is fully aware of and committed to the transparency of its work in all sectors. The Task Force should set up an information center on COVID-19: Work on a regular basis to do coordinating and informative interviews, dissemination of knowledge and more by working with the five specific committees for monitoring and implementation. Explain the name of the society in a proper way that should not be confused or disturbed. Increase the inspection and enforcement of legal measures against fraudulent, disruptive people who spread false information or build against faith in society, as well as people acting in negative ways when coping with the outbreak.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 29, 2020: In addition, the Task Force Committee shall provide detail guidance in a format of an easy understanding to disseminate through official media outlets namely: Khaosaan Pathet Lao, National Television, National Radio, Vientiane Times Newspaper and on the website www.COVID19.gov.la, in order for the concerned agencies and local authorities to use it to further disseminate to wider communities and to instruct and mobilize the entire society to follow the information through official media outlets and be
cautious when consuming information.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description:
April 1, 2020: The Ministry of Post and Telecommunications in cooperation with a Lao ICT company recently launched an official website www.covid19.gov.la so the public can access factual information during the country’s Covid-19 crisis. The site is an information source to distribute the government’s orders, announcements, and measures to control the coronavirus pandemic.
The website contains news reports related to Covid-19 circumstances in Laos as well as methods to prevent members of the public from getting infecting and which symptoms should necessitate a visit to the doctor to check for the virus. Aside from seeking knowledge on the coronavirus, the public can ask questions via the website or call the direct 166 hotline number if you have flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government

description: Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 29, 2020: Strictly prohibit the advertisement, release, forwarding of any fake news via any media platform that can cause misunderstanding, panic and create negative impact on the society. Task the agency for surveillance and response to the social complaints to closely monitor and strictly take action on those offenders.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated 18 March 2020: In the event that a person has traveled from Thailand, with the spread of COVID-19, perform 14 days self-isolating and health monitoring.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated 18 March 2020: In the event that a person has traveled from Thailand, with the spread of COVID-19, perform 14 days self-isolating and health monitoring.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government

description:
March 25, 2020: The Lao Prime Minister addressed the situation regarding the thousands of Lao migrant workers who returned to Laos from Thailand in recent days. He said that the government will continue its strict monitoring of the returnees to ensure they remain in quarantine for 14 days.

Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 24, 2020: Relatives, children, grandchilren, or family members (students and workers) returning to Laos from overseas should self-quarantine for 14 days. Provinces, cities, and healthcare professionals should record details of start and departure dates for people returning from abroad and monitor and record physical conditions.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 24, 2020: Relatives, children, grandchildren, or family members (students and workers) returning to Laos from overseas should self-quarantine for 14 days. Provinces, cities, and healthcare professionals should record details of start and departure dates for people returning from abroad and monitor and record physical conditions. RETURNING MIGRANTS WITH SYMPTOMS will be quarantined in special quarantine facilities. The COVID 19 pandemic has pushed thousands of Lao women and girl migrant workers to return to Laos. According to the latest report on 2 April 2020 from the Immigration Department of Vientiane Municipality Public Security, 4,715 migrants (2,922 females) crossed Lao-Thai Friendship Bridge in Vientiane Capital. As of 25 March 2020, quarantine facilities have been set up by the Government of Lao PDR for those people with symptoms who will be housed there for 14 days.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government

description:
19 Mar 2020, Laos: All entertainment venues including karaoke and massage venues should be closed. Other businesses can continue operations and services with the operators employing necessary protective measures, including taking the temperature of customers and providing alcohol-based hand sanitizer.

Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 23, 2020: Entertainment venues, including karaoke venues, bars, spas, nightmarkets, and other venues of entertainment activities are very crowded and high-risk. For hotels, resorts, guest houses, factories, restaurants, and tourist services: services can be operated normally but owners must enact activities including basic preventive measures, such as temperature monitoring, water supply, hand washing, and limiting the number of people entering the service area without crowding and with safe distances.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
In Laos, starting March 23, all entertainment venues (including karaoke and massage venues, bars, spas, and night markets), should be closed. Other businesses (such as hotels, resorts, guest houses, factories, restaurants, and tourist services) can continue operations with protective measures, including temperature monitoring, providing sanitizer or hand-washing supplies, and limiting capacity.

Night markets, restaurants that have received official authorization, and cinemas abiding by social distancing are allowed to reopen in Laos starting May 29.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From March 30 to April 19, Laos enacted a lockdown, including of business operations. Authorized business sectors include financial institutions, listed companies, medical services, post services, utilities, collection and treatment of waste, agricultural produce markets, retail shops, supermarkets, and restaurants for the provision of takeaway and delivery services only.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description:
19 Mar 2020, Laos: All entertainment venues including karaoke and massage venues should be closed. Other businesses can continue operations and services with the operators employing necessary protective measures, including taking the temperature of customers and providing alcohol-based hand sanitizer.

Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated March 23, 2020: Entertainment venues, including karaoke venues, bars, spas, nightmarkets, and other venues of entertainment activities are very crowded and high-risk. For hotels, resorts, guest houses, factories, restaurants, and tourist services: services can be operated normally but owners must enact activities including basic preventive measures, such as temperature monitoring, water supply, hand washing, and limiting the number of people entering the service area without crowding and with safe distances.

As of June 30, Casinos will be allowed to resume operations, according to the notice, but must also comply with covid prevention measures.

Social gatherings, weddings, parties, and traditional festivals may now be held, however, organizers must follow strict guidelines laid out by the national taskforce.

Meanwhile, entertainment venues including karaoke bars, nightclubs, and internet cafes will remain closed in order to prevent a second wave of the Covid-19 virus appearing in Laos.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated April 2, 2020: Let each ministry, agency and all parties consider which parties should be employed to do normal work. Ministries, agencies and parties are allowed to continue to work regularly or to dispose of their employees. People can work according to the merits and the necessity of the work. No crowds at the office.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government

description:
Lao People's Democratic Republic Prime Minister's Order, dated April 2, 2020: Let each ministry, agency and all parties consider which parties should be employed to do normal work. Ministries, agencies and parties are allowed to continue to work regularly or to dispose of their employees. People can work according to the merits and the necessity of the work. No crowds at the office. 

The government is permitting Party and state offices and private businesses to resume operations on Monday (May 4) as normal while continuing to strictly observe coronavirus prevention measures.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government

description:
VIENTIANE (Vientiane Times/ANN): Business operators in Xieng Khuang province are feeling the impact of the postponement of the National Games which had been scheduled for March 22 to April 1.

With Laos lacking widespread health infrastructure and medical supplies, authorities decided to postpone the games to reduce the risk of an outbreak of Covid-19.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government

description: March 25, 2020: Lao Prime Minister Thongloun Sisoulith has advised all citizens of Laos to practice self-isolation and social distancing to better protect themselves and each other. The Prime Minister made the recommendation at a press conference held by the National Task Force Committee for the Prevention and Control of Covid-19 held earlier today.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Laos: The government looks set to keep some strict measures in place as part of its bold policy to control the spread of COVID-19, following a high-level meeting in Vientiane. According to a government media release, the Prime Minister-Deputy Prime Minister Meeting on April 28 agreed in principle that some strict measures under the PM Order No. 06 would remain active after its expiration. The government enacted and extended the PM order until May 3, which demands people not leave their homes except for essential reasons as part of efforts to curb the spread of the COVID-19 outbreak in the country.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Military,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police
